interfaces.description: TODO this type is used for the backend payload as well as the frontend interface before saving the scenario. This is bad, as the types are not the same. For example, treatment_question only exists on the FE but does not exists on the backend payload. Similarly, question_id only exists on the backend payload, while on the FE side this is part of treatment_question.
interfaces.rawdescription:
TODO this type is used for the backend payload
as well as the frontend interface before saving the scenario.
This is bad, as the types are not the same.
For example, `treatment_question` only exists on the FE but does not exists on
the backend payload.
Similarly, `question_id` only exists on the backend payload, while on the FE side
this is part of `treatment_question`.

properties.name: availableRegions
properties.defaultValue:
new Set([
    Region.SIERRA_NEVADA,
    this.features.isFeatureEnabled('show_socal')
      ? Region.SOUTHERN_CALIFORNIA
      : null,
    this.features.isFeatureEnabled('show_centralcoast')
      ? Region.CENTRAL_COAST
      : null,
    this.features.isFeatureEnabled('show_north_cal')
      ? Region.NORTHERN_CALIFORNIA
      : null,
  ])

components.name: AboutComponent

propertiesClass.name: bulletPoints
propertiesClass.defaultValue:
[
    'Open source and free to use, for state and federal planners, as well as the public',
    'Supports regional planning for fire resilience and ecological benefits across broader landscapes',
    'Utilizes the latest Regional Resource Kits as the primary data source',
    'Incorporates the best state and federal science and models',
  ]

components.templateData:
Planscape is a new wildfire resilience planning tool

Designed to bring the best available state & federal data and science together, Planscape guides regional planners in identifying the optimal landscapes to treat in order to mitigate fire risk, maximize ecological benefits, and help California's landscapes adapt to climate change.

{{ bullet }}

The data used is based on California's Regional Resource Kits, developed by the California Wildfire & Forest Resilience Task Force. You can find more detailed information about these here.

components.name: ChipInputComponent
components.templateData:
<mat-form-field appearance="outline">
  <mat-chip-list #chipList aria-label="Emails">
    <mat-chip *ngFor="let email of emails" (removed)="removeEmail.emit(email)">
      {{ email }}
      <button matChipRemove>
        <mat-icon>close</mat-icon>
      </button>
    </mat-chip>
    <input
      cdkFocusInitial
      type="email"
      matInput
      [placeholder]="placeholder"
      [matChipInputFor]="chipList"
      [matChipInputAddOnBlur]="true"
      (matChipInputTokenEnd)="addIfValid($event)" />
  </mat-chip-list>
</mat-form-field>

components.name: ConditionTreeComponent

propertiesClass.name: hasChild
propertiesClass.description: Used to compute whether a node in the condition layer tree has children.
propertiesClass.rawdescription: Used to compute whether a node in the condition layer tree has children.

propertiesClass.name: treeFlattener
propertiesClass.defaultValue:
new MatTreeFlattener(
    this._transformer,
    (node) => node.level,
    (node) => node.expandable,
    (node) => node.children
  )

components.name: DetailsComponent
components.templateData:
<app-form-message
  [messageType]="FormMessageType.SUCCESS"
  *ngIf="successMsg"
  title="Success!"
  message="{{ successMsg }}">
</app-form-message>

<app-form-message
  [messageType]="FormMessageType.ERROR"
  *ngIf="errorMsg"
  title="Error!"
  message="{{ errorMsg }}">
</app-form-message>

<app-edit-user-field
  userField="firstName"
  [currentValue]="(user$ | async)?.firstName || ''"
  (saved)="successMsg = $event"
  (failed)="errorMsg = $event"></app-edit-user-field>
<app-edit-user-field
  userField="lastName"
  [currentValue]="(user$ | async)?.lastName || ''"
  (saved)="successMsg = $event"
  (failed)="errorMsg = $event"></app-edit-user-field>

components.name: InfoCardComponent
components.templateData:
With a Planscape account, you can:

Create plans, scenarios and project areas

Test different land management options and view outcomes

Save planning areas

Download shapefiles and metadata from your plans

Share work with collaborators

As a guest user, you can:

Explore data from the Regional Resource Kits

View publicly available plans and scenarios*

*Accessible only via direct links

Review Planscape Conditions of Use

we need to find the same config instance from boundaryConfig$ as the one
saved in map.config, so the map config panel shows the same right selection.
TODO: avoid this, save only the boundary config id or something that we can
easily identify rather than the whole object (which drives this issue)

ISSUE this is happening with the "old" boundary config.

Share {{ data.planningAreaName }}

People with access

{{ planCreator$ | async }}
Owner
{{ fullname$ | async }} (You)
Owner
{{ invite.collaborator_name || invite.email }}

Help

How do I restrict permission to access a planning area?

When you share a planning area with someone, you can choose their permission level.

Owner:

People who created the planning area. The owner can choose who can collaborate or only view the scenarios of a planning area.

Collaborator:

Collaborators can create and archive scenarios of a planning area shared with them, but they cannot share the planning area/scenarios with others.

Viewer:

Viewers can view a planning area, but they cant create or archive scenarios, and share the planning area with others.

components.name: WelcomeComponent
components.templateData:
Welcome to Planscape!

What is Planscape?

Planscape is a new wildfire resilience planning support tool designed to bring the best available state & federal data together with the latest science to enable better land management. Planscape is built to help regional wildland planners prioritize landscape treatments. With Planscape, you can mitigate fire risk, maximize ecological benefits, and help landscapes adapt to climate change.

Planscape includes all data from the Regional Resource Kit layers for the Sierra Nevada, Southern California, Central Coast and Northern California regions.

What can I do with Planscape?

You can view and explore the landscape resilience planning data on a set of maps. You can also visualize this data for the four regions alongside other provided data sets such as county and watershed boundaries.

Future Planscape releases aim to give you the ability to create and save planning areas, to create scenarios for various treatments, and to collaborate with other stakeholders.

Can Planscape actually help with planning?

Yes! A lot more functionality, including the ability to create, edit, save, and share plans is coming. The tool will also include integration with ForSys to allow planners to output projects that are optimized within provided constraints.

How do I do more?

Click on the Help icon on the top right corner of the tool to read the user guide or check out the Planscape Release Notes or FAQ . You can also visit Planscape.org for more information about the tool. If you would like to receive our newsletter for regular updates, you can sign up here .

How can I get started?

If you want to use the Regional Resource Kit mapping tool, click Explore.

Explore

Already have an account? Click here to login or create an account.

Please read our Conditions of Use for information regarding usage of this tool.

variables.name: WINDOW
variables.description:
Window service This service provides a way of getting the window object via a dependency injection This allows to mock and provide the window object as well as applying best practices.

How it works? The main idea is to provide a token when using window instead of referencing window object directly.

Avoid this:

Example :
export class YourComponent {

  getAgent() {
    window.navigator.userAgent;
  }
}

Use this instead:

Example :
export class YourComponent {

 constructor(@Inject(WINDOW) private window: Window)

  getAgent() {
    this.window.navigator.userAgent;
  }
}

There are several ways of implementing this idea, this one is taken from https://brianflove.com/2018-01-11/angular-window-provider/

Testing

You can provide a mock of the window object when declaring your test module

await TestBed.configureTestingModule({ declarations: [YourComponent], providers: [ { provide: WINDOW, useValue: { YourWindowMock }, }, ], }).compileComponents();

And then get the window reference on your tests

Example :
const window = TestBed.inject(WINDOW);

src/app/services/window.service.ts.description:
Window service This service provides a way of getting the window object via a dependency injection This allows to mock and provide the window object as well as applying best practices.

How it works? The main idea is to provide a token when using window instead of referencing window object directly.

Avoid this:

Example :
export class YourComponent {

  getAgent() {
    window.navigator.userAgent;
  }
}

Use this instead:

Example :
export class YourComponent {

 constructor(@Inject(WINDOW) private window: Window)

  getAgent() {
    this.window.navigator.userAgent;
  }
}

There are several ways of implementing this idea, this one is taken from https://brianflove.com/2018-01-11/angular-window-provider/

Testing

You can provide a mock of the window object when declaring your test module

await TestBed.configureTestingModule({ declarations: [YourComponent], providers: [ { provide: WINDOW, useValue: { YourWindowMock }, }, ], }).compileComponents();

And then get the window reference on your tests

Example :
const window = TestBed.inject(WINDOW);
